SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A NOTE ON COMPLETION OF THIS QUESTIONNAIRE

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experience; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about answering blank spaces. Use the attached sheets if necessary. There is little point in answering the questions if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1934 and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

OTHER QUESTIONNAIRES

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Life: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Think?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark this ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer housing, life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All Questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office
University of Saskatchewan
Saskatoon, Sask.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCE: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A VITAL COMPLEMENTARY TO THIS QUESTIONNAIRE

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experience, whereas others may prove important for you to answer, even though they do not apply to anyone else.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1921, but may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years in another part of this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

OTHER QUESTIONNAIRES

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Life: What Did Western Canadians Pioneer?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and are willing to do so, please put a check mark here and we will be glad to send you a copy.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer:

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer health, diet, sports and recreation
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's collection at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our province. Please send your completed questionnaires to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

5. What was your father's name and occupation?
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) June 13th, 1889.
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not, or you may use "I was in my teens," etc.) 18 years old.
9. What were your reasons for coming West?

The west was opening up; my uncle had come out, my father knew the land was good for farming.

My father fell on the thunder creek, he walked on land, then he fell on the creek, my father got sick.

Carnduff was settled by my parents by ox team.

I came here because I wanted to farm.
